definitions.definition: ( finance , transitive ) To endeavour to depress the price of, or prices in.
examples: to bear a railroad stock
to bear the market

main_definition: ( finance , transitive ) To endeavour to depress the price of, or prices in.

definitions.definition: To carry or convey , literally or figuratively.
examples: They came bearing gifts.
Judging from the look on his face, he wasn't bearing good news.
The little boat bore us to our destination.
This plant's light and fluffy seeds may be borne by the wind to remote islands.
what the market will bear

subdefinitions.definition: To carry (weapons, flags or symbols of rank, office, etc.) upon one's person, especially visibly; to be equipped with (weapons, etc.).
examples: the right to bear arms

subdefinitions.definition: To wear (garments, pieces of jewellery, etc.).
examples: The queen bore the royal scepter and crown as she processed into the hall.

subdefinitions.definition: To carry ( offspring in the womb ), to be pregnant (with).
examples: The scan showed that the ewe was bearing twins.
labels: of a woman or female animal
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , rarely intransitive , of a woman or female animal

subdefinitions.definition: To have or display (a mark or other feature).
examples: She still bears the scars from a cycling accident.
The stone bears a short inscription.
This bears all the hallmarks of a terrorist attack.

subdefinitions.definition: To display (a particular heraldic device) on a shield or coat of arms; to be entitled to wear or use (a heraldic device) as a coat of arms.
examples: The shield bore a red cross.

subdefinitions.definition: To present or exhibit (a particular outward appearance); to have (a certain look).
examples: He bore the look of a defeated man.

subdefinitions.definition: To have (a name, title, or designation).
examples: The school still bears the name of its founder.

subdefinitions.definition: To possess or enjoy (recognition, renown, a reputation, etc.); to have (a particular price, value, or worth).
examples: The dictator bears a terrible reputation for cruelty.

subdefinitions.definition: To have ( interest or a specified rate of interest) stipulated in its terms .
examples: The bond bears a fixed interest rate of 3.5%.
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , of an investment, loan, etc.

subdefinitions.definition: To have (an appendage, organ, etc.) as part of the body; ( of a part of the body ) to have (an appendage).
examples: Only the male Indian elephant bears tusks.
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , of a person or animal

subdefinitions.definition: To carry or hold in the mind; to experience, entertain, harbour (an idea, feeling, or emotion).
examples: to bear a grudge , to bear ill will

subdefinitions.definition: To feel and show (respect, reverence, loyalty, etc.) to, towards, or unto a person or thing.
examples: The brothers had always borne one another respect.

subdefinitions.definition: To possess inherently (a quality, attribute, power, or capacity); to have and display as an essential characteristic.
examples: to bear life

subdefinitions.definition: To have (a relation, correspondence, etc.) to something else.
examples: The punishment bears no relation to the crime.

subdefinitions.definition: To give (written or oral testimony or evidence); (figurative) to provide or constitute (evidence or proof), give witness .
examples: His achievements bear testimony to his ability.
The jury could see he was bearing false witness.

subdefinitions.definition: To have (a certain meaning, intent, or effect).
examples: This word no longer bears its original meaning.

subdefinitions.definition: To behave or conduct (oneself).
examples: She bore herself well throughout the ordeal.

subdefinitions.definition: To possess and use, to exercise (power or influence); to hold (an office, rank, or position).
To carry a burden or burdens.
To take or bring (a person) with oneself; to conduct .
To support or sustain ; to hold up .
examples: This stone bears most of the weight.

subdefinitions.definition: To endure or withstand ( hardship , scrutiny , etc.); to tolerate ; to be patient (with).
examples: The pain is too much for me to bear .
It doesn’t bear thinking about.
I would never move to Texas — I can't bear heat.
This reasoning will not bear much analysis.
Please bear with me as I try to find the book you need.
labels: now transitive outside certain set patterns such as 'bear with'
subdefinitions.label_groups: now transitive outside certain set patterns such as 'bear with'; formerly also intransitive

subdefinitions.definition: To sustain, or be answerable for (blame, expense, responsibility, etc.).
examples: The hirer must bear the cost of any repairs.

subdefinitions.definition: To admit or be capable of (a meaning); to suffer or sustain without violence, injury, or change.
To warrant , justify the need for.
examples: This storm definitely bears monitoring.

definitions.definition: To support, keep up, or maintain.

subdefinitions.definition: To afford, to be something to someone, to supply with something. (Can we add an example for this sense?)
To carry on, or maintain; to have. (Can we add an example for this sense?)
To push, thrust, press .
examples: The rope has frayed where it bears on the rim of the wheel.
subdefinitions.label_groups: intransitive , usually with on , upon , or against

subdefinitions.definition: To take effect; to have influence or force; to be relevant.
examples: to bring arguments to bear
How does this bear on the question?

subdefinitions.definition: Of a weapon, to be aimed at an enemy or other target.
examples: The cannons were wheeled around to bear upon the advancing troops.
subdefinitions.label_groups: intransitive , military , usually with on or upon

definitions.definition: To produce, yield, give birth to.

subdefinitions.definition: To give birth to (someone or something) ( may take the father of the direct object as an indirect object ) .
examples: In Troy she becomes Paris’ wife, bearing him several children, all of whom die in infancy.
The twins were borne by an Italian mother.

subdefinitions.definition: To produce or yield something, such as fruit or crops.
examples: This year our apple trees bore a good crop of fruit.

definitions.definition: To be, or head , in a specific direction or azimuth (from somewhere).
examples: Carry on past the church and then bear left at the junction.
By my readings, we're bearing due south, so we should turn about ten degrees east.
Great Falls bears north of Bozeman.

main_definition: ( chiefly transitive ) To carry or convey , literally or figuratively.
secondary_definitions: To support, keep up, or maintain.
To produce, yield, give birth to.
( intransitive , originally nautical ) To be, or head , in a specific direction or azimuth (from somewhere).
( transitive , obsolete ) To gain or win .
